attributes.mlflow.spanInputs:
{"query": "What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?", "context": [{"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "b1808eab-025b-424c-a6e7-62da603153f6", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "644a9f38-2775-4876-a039-5f53c148473e", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "86b5dd6f-f1cf-4194-854b-ba48e57bcda5", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/integrating-sagemaker.md", "_id": "1194a9f0-8040-4303-a3c9-d20a71f95a74", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.", "type": "Document"}]}
attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"result": "AWS SageMaker Geospatial capabilities refer to the features and functionalities of Amazon SageMaker that allow users to perform geospatial operations and analysis on their data. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker and executed on AWS hardware. However, the operations that can be performed are limited to those permitted by the user.

To use SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and cannot do within AWS. An execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. The execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy that specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

To create an execution role for SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you can use the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess. This policy grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. If your use case requires more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs by following other sections of the guide.

It's important to note that SageMaker Geospatial capabilities are fully managed by AWS, meaning that you don't have to manage servers or infrastructure to use them. This allows data scientists and developers to quickly and easily build and train machine learning models that can perform geospatial analysis, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. Additionally, SageMaker provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, and you can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager."}

It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"output_text": "AWS SageMaker Geospatial capabilities refer to the features and functionalities of Amazon SageMaker that allow users to perform geospatial operations and analysis on their data. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker and executed on AWS hardware. However, the operations that can be performed are limited to those permitted by the user.

To use SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and cannot do within AWS. An execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. The execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy that specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

To create an execution role for SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you can use the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess. This policy grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. If your use case requires more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs by following other sections of the guide.

It's important to note that SageMaker Geospatial capabilities are fully managed by AWS, meaning that you don't have to manage servers or infrastructure to use them. This allows data scientists and developers to quickly and easily build and train machine learning models that can perform geospatial analysis, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. Additionally, SageMaker provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, and you can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager."}

attributes.mlflow.spanInputs:
{"question": "What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?", "context": "SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.

Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.

How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide."}
attributes.mlflow.spanOutputs:
{"text": "AWS SageMaker Geospatial capabilities refer to the features and functionalities of Amazon SageMaker that allow users to perform geospatial operations and analysis on their data. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker and executed on AWS hardware. However, the operations that can be performed are limited to those permitted by the user.

To use SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and cannot do within AWS. An execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. The execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy that specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

To create an execution role for SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you can use the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess. This policy grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. If your use case requires more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs by following other sections of the guide.

It's important to note that SageMaker Geospatial capabilities are fully managed by AWS, meaning that you don't have to manage servers or infrastructure to use them. This allows data scientists and developers to quickly and easily build and train machine learning models that can perform geospatial analysis, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. Additionally, SageMaker provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, and you can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager."}

attributes.text:
Prompt after formatting:
[32;1m[1;3m
<s>[INST]
System: 
You are an AI assistant that helps users with answering queries about documentation. You have access to a large collection of documents 
from AWS documentation, particularly SageMaker and have to answer in details and explain clearly.

User: 
Please answer my question about AWS documentation only based on provided context.


-----------
This is the context:
SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.

Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.

How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.

-----------
This is the question:
What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?

[/INST]
[0m

{"query": "What are SageMaker Geospatial capabilities?", "context": [{"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "b1808eab-025b-424c-a6e7-62da603153f6", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "SageMaker geospatial capabilities roles

As a managed service, Amazon SageMaker geospatial capabilities perform operations on your behalf on the AWS hardware that is managed by SageMaker. It can perform only operations that the user permits.

A user can grant these permissions with an IAM role (referred to as an execution role).

To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "644a9f38-2775-4876-a039-5f53c148473e", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "To create and use a locally available execution role, you can use the following procedures.

Create an execution role

To work with SageMaker geospatial capabilities you need to setup a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and can not do within AWS. An execution role is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. An execution role consists of permissions and trust policy. The trust policy specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

Use the following procedure to create an execution role with the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, attached. If your use case requires more granular permissions, use other sections of this guide to create an execution role that meets your business needs.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/sagemaker-geospatial-roles.md", "_id": "86b5dd6f-f1cf-4194-854b-ba48e57bcda5", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "Important The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess, used in the following procedure only grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. To learn how to add an additional policy to an execution role to grant it access to other Amazon S3 buckets and objects, see Add Additional Amazon S3 Permissions to a SageMaker Execution Role.

To create a new role

Open the IAM console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/.

Select Roles and then select Create role.

Select SageMaker.

Select Next: Permissions.

The IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess is automatically attached to this role. To see the permissions included in this policy, select the sideways arrow next to the policy name. Select Next: Tags.

(Optional) Add tags and select Next: Review.", "type": "Document"}, {"id": null, "metadata": {"source": "./data/sagemaker_documentation/integrating-sagemaker.md", "_id": "1194a9f0-8040-4303-a3c9-d20a71f95a74", "_collection_name": "sagemaker_documentation_v2"}, "page_content": "How Amazon SageMaker uses AWS Secrets Manager

SageMaker is a fully managed machine learning service. With SageMaker, data scientists and developers can quickly and easily build and train machine learning models, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. It provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, so you don't have to manage servers.

You can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager. For more information, see Associate Git Repositories with Amazon SageMaker Notebook Instances in the Amazon SageMaker Developer Guide.", "type": "Document"}]}
response:
{"result": "AWS SageMaker Geospatial capabilities refer to the features and functionalities of Amazon SageMaker that allow users to perform geospatial operations and analysis on their data. These capabilities are managed by SageMaker and executed on AWS hardware. However, the operations that can be performed are limited to those permitted by the user.

To use SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you need to set up both a user role and an execution role. A user role is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the user can and cannot do within AWS. An execution role, on the other hand, is an IAM role that grants the service permission to access your AWS resources. The execution role consists of permissions and a trust policy that specifies which principals have the permission to assume the role.

To create an execution role for SageMaker Geospatial capabilities, you can use the IAM managed policy, AmazonSageMakerGeospatialFullAccess. This policy grants the execution role permission to perform certain Amazon S3 actions on buckets or objects with SageMaker, Sagemaker, sagemaker, or aws-glue in the name. If your use case requires more granular permissions, you can create an execution role that meets your business needs by following other sections of the guide.

It's important to note that SageMaker Geospatial capabilities are fully managed by AWS, meaning that you don't have to manage servers or infrastructure to use them. This allows data scientists and developers to quickly and easily build and train machine learning models that can perform geospatial analysis, and then directly deploy them into a production-ready hosted environment. Additionally, SageMaker provides an integrated Jupyter authoring notebook instance for easy access to your data sources for exploration and analysis, and you can associate Git repositories with your Jupyter notebook instances to save your notebooks in a source control environment that persists even if you stop or delete your notebook instance. You can manage your private repositories credentials using Secrets Manager."}
